column1:
For many people, Our Flag Means Death was an unexpected history lesson about the adventures of Stede Bonnet, the real 18th-century pirate who loved the high seas almost as much as he loathed the â€œdiscomfortsâ€ of married life with his wife. Our Flag Means Deathâ€™s first season often leaned into the absurd as it followed Rhys Darbyâ€™s interpretation of Bonnet putting together a crew of vagabonds willing to serve under a soft and inexperienced member of the landed gentry playing a pirate. But what makes the showâ€™s story work â€” aside from how much of it really does borrow elements from the real Bonnetâ€™s life â€” is how itâ€™s really only about piracy in the most roundabout sense.

Surprised as many viewers were to learn that the real Stede and Blackbeard did spend a significant amount of time traveling together, what ended throwing many of Our Flag Means Deathâ€™s viewers for a loop was the revelation that its Stede and Blackbeard were falling in love. Of all the clever tricks â€” or fuckery, if youâ€™d prefer â€” Our Flag Means Death managed to pull off, few were impressive as its ability to disguise the fact that it was a period romance all along, something series creator David Jenkins partially attributes to the expectations we bring to TV. When we spoke with Jenkins recently, he said that while itâ€™s been great watching fans embrace Our Flag Means Death, the surprised responses to its character arcs speak to the importance of using genre fiction to better reflect and play with the realities of our world.

Before we talk about Stede and Ed, letâ€™s talk about David and Taika as showrunner and executive producer.

David Jenkins: For me, the joy of having an EP like Taika is that you know heâ€™s there and is going to come direct the pilot, but then he just leaves me alone, and I get to make the show as weird as I want to make it. We get to take it in the writers room in directions that interest us, and no oneâ€™s trying to get in there and fuck with it too much. The great thing about Taika is that he comes back. He does actually direct the pilot â€” he doesnâ€™t float away â€” and he decides that itâ€™s well-written enough that he wants to be in it. And then he performs your fucking writing!

Thereâ€™s moments of improvisation, but like the amount that heâ€™s served those scripts and the amount that heâ€™s served my vision for what the show should be is humbling. When youâ€™re looking at this person whoâ€™s incredible and itâ€™s like, â€œAh, man. Theyâ€™re playing my notes. Oh my god, this is incredible.â€ Itâ€™s immensely gratifying.

Is that something one hopes for, but one doesnâ€™t bank on happening?

Itâ€™s rare, but I think thatâ€™s why heâ€™s a very good producer. I donâ€™t know a ton about his relationship with Sterlin [Harjo] on Reservation Dogs, but thatâ€™s Sterlinâ€™s thing. He conceived it with Taika, but Sterlin is the driving force behind that show and what it looks like, and I think part of being a good producer is knowing when to go away and when to come back. Setting people up whose sensibilities you like, and then championing them, and supporting them without trying to control it too much is an amazing skill that I think very few people of his stature have.

What is it about Our Flag Means Death that made it so easy for people to really sort of miss the early queer subtext thatâ€™s barely subtext?

Iâ€™m the wrong person to ask because I, well, I know a lot more now than I did a month ago, and I know a lot more now than I did two weeks ago based on how this show was going to roll out. I thought it was pretty clear to me that you get halfway through, and youâ€™re like, â€œOh, OK. These people have feelings for each other. And theyâ€™re attracted to each other.â€

Little bit, yeah.

And itâ€™s clear. I think I didnâ€™t realize â€” because I see myself represented on camera, and I see myself falling in love in stories â€” I didnâ€™t realize how deep the queer baiting thing goes. Being made to feel stupid by stories, I guess.

How do you mean?

As we were breaking the season and looking at how it would go, part of me knew that, yes, Stede and Edâ€™s romance was going to be real. But one part of me felt like, â€œWeâ€™re going to do this story, and theyâ€™re going to kiss, and maybe thatâ€™s not even going to be that big a deal. Maybe itâ€™ll just be a blip.â€ But then, looking at how people were kind of afraid to let themselves believe that we were doing that was a surprise to me, and itâ€™s heartbreaking.

I understand it much better now, and itâ€™s like, oh, you were made to feel stupid by a bunch of shows â€” unintentionally, by and large, I think â€” but made to feel like â€œmaybe Iâ€™m going to be up there. Maybe thatâ€™ll be me in this story.â€ And then at the end of it feeling like, â€œAw. No, itâ€™s not me. Iâ€™m not in this one.â€ That fucks with you at any age, I think, but especially when youâ€™re young and impressionable. I know it would make me feel that I didnâ€™t belong, and I think thatâ€™s part of where the response to the show comes from.

Take me back to when you were first breaking the season and carving out your take on Stede and Ed. What was the key to building out romance between the two of them that felt organic and honest to them both? Not as historical figures but as characters taking shape in your mind?

Iâ€™d never written a romance before this one, but I think with Ed and Stede, the questionâ€™s always â€œwhatâ€™s the need for each other?â€ I think the need for Stede is pretty apparent in the beginning because heâ€™s just this poor man who doesnâ€™t know at all what heâ€™s doing. Ed, I think, is at a point in his life where he needs to see somebody whoâ€™s a bit of an outsider artist who has a fresh take on piracy. Once you figure out what these kinds of characters are missing â€” what theyâ€™re looking for in each other â€” their stories start to take on their own lives, and they reveal things to you. Like, Stedeâ€™s such a great character because he unwittingly seduces this person by being his neat self and doing stuff in a slightly different way.

This is the first time Iâ€™ve heard anyone talk about the show through the Stede-as-seducer lens, but youâ€™re totally right. Thereâ€™s that one line where he asks Blackbeard if he â€œfancies a fine fabric,â€ and it killed me because thatâ€™s a whole 18th-century pickup line. Heâ€™s cruising.

Itâ€™s an unintentional seduction, I think, but yeah.

Talk to me about that â€” the unintentionality of Stedeâ€™s seduction and leading with that from a writing perspective.

Itâ€™s just that undeniable chemistry between two people falling in love at first sight, essentially. When they see each other, itâ€™s that Beach Boys â€œOur Prayerâ€ song that our editor Daniel Haworth pitched, and itâ€™s just fantastic in that moment. I donâ€™t know. I love looking at them as having a modern relationship where, you know, maybe youâ€™ve heard about each other before you met, and then youâ€™re kind of into what the other personâ€™s doing, and then it turns out that theyâ€™re into what youâ€™re doing. And then you see each other, and thereâ€™s chemistry?

But then also, I think thereâ€™s something interesting about an amateur going up against the ultimate professional. Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ve seen it, too â€” youâ€™re overworked. But when you see someone whoâ€™s writing for fun, and youâ€™re fucking tired and jaded, and you had a bunch of stupid shit happen, but you see that people whoâ€™s still feeling it? You remember, â€œOh, right. Thatâ€™s why I do it. This is what I need to get back to. Like, what the fuck? What am I doing?â€

Definitely.

I think â€œdo you fancy a fine fabricâ€ is unintentional, but itâ€™s when he tucks the fabric into Blackbeardâ€™s shirt and tells him that he wears fine things well that makes it work. Thatâ€™s such a kind thing to say and such a perceptive thing for him to say in that moment, and sometimes you meet somebody and you can just see them like that.

Youâ€™ve talked in the past about framing Stede as a really naive person with an immature sense of love before meeting Ed because heâ€™d just never really experienced it before. What about Edâ€™s sense of love and romance, though? Heâ€™s this worldly person whoâ€™s already exhausted and put upon by his life Pre-Gentleman Pirate.

Yeah, I think theyâ€™re both very undeveloped in certain ways, but I think this is Edâ€™s first time falling in love, too, honestly. Heâ€™s more experienced, and heâ€™s, I think, probably more physically experienced than Stede. But theyâ€™re these two middle-aged men who are underdeveloped in a certain way in terms of romantic emotional health as we understand it. It made sense to have that love be almost like a teenage version of falling in love â€” one with all these intense and conflicting feelings. Theyâ€™re middle-aged, but Stedeâ€™s young. Edâ€™s young. Emotionally, theyâ€™re like 16, and theyâ€™ve both got a lot to learn.

I want to talk to you about the final episode of the first season and that sort of pointed change that we see both of them go through once that classic misunderstanding has sort of been introduced, right? Stedeâ€™s â€œCrap, I do love him. I have to go get him.â€ Edâ€™s like, â€œHeâ€™s left me.â€ And that sort of feels as if theyâ€™ve branched off into two defined states that arenâ€™t just going to be temporary. In that moment when they are sort of not in sync with each other anymore, what do they mean to each other?

I mean, I think itâ€™s two sides of the same coin, which is why we use montage a couple of times at the end of that episode, and why it was important to me that it was scripted that way. Stedeâ€™s realizing heâ€™s in love and finding out that he is actually in love is a surprise to him. It didnâ€™t even occur to him that he got it right, and then Mary has to kind of tell him. I think Blackbeard feels like heâ€™s never been rejected in this way before. So in a weird way, Stedeâ€™s feeling love â€” like a more mature version of love than heâ€™s ever felt, and Blackbeardâ€™s feeling a more profound, mature version of rejection. Because heâ€™s never put himself out there like this, and itâ€™s deranging him because heâ€™s a highly emotional person.

Thereâ€™s so many moments where Izzyâ€™s opposition to Stede can be read as like, â€œPlease stop fucking with my boss. Youâ€™re ruining our good thing here,â€ but that in and of itself also reads as a form of love between Izzy and Ed. As you were building out Izzyâ€™s arc, what were the really important beats that you wanted for him to sort of land on as he keeps sort of being this thorn in the side of this burgeoning romance?

I think the key was casting Con. The part was written before we got him, and then we had a few scripts left to go, and I knew we had Con, and I would actually watch his audition to get back to Izzyâ€™s center. He plays an exhausted quality thatâ€™s really lovely because this character could just be generically evil, and the way Con plays, it is like, heâ€™s credible. I believe that he can do some damage if he wanted to. My favorite thing Iâ€™ve seen about the show is somebody saying that Conâ€™s playing the only human with a bunch of Muppets. It does feel like that a bit where heâ€™s like Charles Grodin in The Great Muppet Caper.

Thereâ€™s a lot of Muppet Treasure Island here.

Yeah! And then and then, at the same time, I think Izzyâ€™s deeply in love with Blackbeard, and itâ€™s a very dysfunctional kind of love, and heâ€™s like the jilted spouse whoâ€™s losing his man to fucking Stede Bonnet, and he canâ€™t believe this is happening.

So much of this show is about romance, but itâ€™s also like a very clever deconstruction of our ideas about masculinity. What sort of conversations did you have with the other writers about making sure that this was always going to be a show about pirates inhabiting different modes of being as opposed to, you know, Men On the High Seas?

I feel like, particularly over the last five years, weâ€™ve been treated to this burlesque of masculinity.

How do you mean?

Well, itâ€™s meaningless, but you look at people going â€œlook at President [Trump],â€ and theyâ€™re drawing him like a stereotypical macho man, but in actuality, heâ€™s this doughy sack of shit in a suit. You look at Fox News, which is also an interesting burlesque of straight femininity and masculinity, but itâ€™s done through this really distorted, almost pro-wrestling-like lens. It always felt oppressive to me growing up, and now weâ€™ve hit this place where some people are really trying to hang onto these outdated ideas about gender, but societyâ€™s actually moving on and past them. I think just to take this very hetero, whitewashed genre and write into it more of what it actually was. There were a lot of pirates who were genderfluid, like Anne Bonny and Mary Read, who were doing the pirate thing before anyone was really talking about women getting into piracy. And then, as we were writing more into the shipâ€™s queer culture, we realized that this is just more of what it was.

Do you think of the show as a reexamination of the record in that sense?

Well, no, because at the same time, you wouldnâ€™t want to meet the real Blackbeard. The real Blackbeard was a rapist who handed women over to his crew. The real Stede Bonnet was a slave owner. When we tell these stories, we have to be clear with what weâ€™re doing because all of these people were despicable. To make a fictionalized version of this history, though, I think you have to try to staff a room where people have lived-in experiences that they can bring to the story, and we have to talk about things weâ€™re experiencing now because these stories are timeless.

In talking to the room while we were building it, we kept asking, â€œWhat do we want the show to be?â€ And the consensus in that very diverse room was that we wanted to show that isnâ€™t just wallowing in trauma. We donâ€™t have to do a coming out scene or focusing on the trauma of it â€” not to say that those stories arenâ€™t valid. But we wanted a show where these characters can exist in a fantasy world and their race or gayness doesnâ€™t automatically lead to a traumatic storyline for them. We have a lot of shows where...

Thatâ€™s the point?

Yeah, someoneâ€™s sexuality in a period piece is met with dire consequences. We have a lot that, you know? So what if we just didnâ€™t do it.

When you meet the nun who raised Jim in â€œThis Is Happening,â€ sheâ€™s so matter-of-fact about them having always been more or less the way they are and raising them to seek revenge.

We had so many different permutations of the nun, and it was just great. Like, Iâ€™m old, man, so when Iâ€™m talking about these things, Iâ€™m trying to keep up with everyone and understand and ask the right questions. When you staff your room well, theyâ€™ll lead you there if you listen and say, â€œWhat can we do with this nun beyond the obvious?â€

I feel like thatâ€™s very much a thing creators talk about now â€” the importance of making sure that their rooms have that kind of dynamism and diversity in them, but Iâ€™m curious to hear what those things mean to you as the creator of something like Our Flag Means Death.

I donâ€™t know how anyone else does it, but for me, I think gender balance is great in a room, and non-binary writers are a part of that. The first thing is, can you write? Do I want to go on a 20-week car trip with you and vice versa? â€œYes, andâ€ is the most important thing in the room because if you get people who are â€œno, but,â€ the work is heavier on everyoneâ€™s shoulders, and then it is really just being like, â€œWho were the most interesting writers out there?â€ There is a demographic component to it that I think people shy away from, but it is what it is. I know that I want X, Y and Z perspectives in the room.

The show about the slave-owning pirate should probably have some people of color in the writersâ€™ room.

Right, and itâ€™s not checking off a diversity list with a golf pencil but really being honest with yourself and asking, â€œDo I have the perspectives and terms of race, gender, sexuality to create a shared sociological imagination?â€ Itâ€™s fucked up because you write a show and a lot of the plaudits go to you, the showrunner, and itâ€™s like youâ€™re using all of these brains. You know, you have this horsepower of all of these writers like this. The season is the function of all of these brains coming together and creating one sociological imagination.

Our Flag Means Death is now streaming on HBO Max.

After launching as â€œIMDb Freediveâ€ back in 2019, IMDb TV quickly faded into the background of the ongoing streaming wars that parent company Amazon had already established a respectable foothold in. While that initial rebrand never quite managed to put the fledgling platform and its content on the map, Amazonâ€™s just announced its plan to reintroduce the streamer yet again under new branding ahead of a massive content push.

In a press release detailing its vision for Freeveeâ€™s future, director Ashraf Alkarmi framed the service as a supplemental platform meant to appeal to consumers interested in watching â€œpremiumâ€ series and films with significantly fewer commercial interruptions.

â€œCustomers are increasingly shifting to streaming ad-supported premium content, and we have developed Freevee to deliver them highly sought content with half the commercials of traditional TV,â€ Alkarmi said. â€œOur new name clearly communicates who we are: An easy-to-navigate streaming service, available to users for free, whenever and wherever they choose to watch some of the greatest Original and licensed content available.â€

When Russell T. Daviesâ€™ original Queer as Folk first premiered on Channel 4 back in 1999, it made a name for itself with its frank and often joyful depictions of queer lives with a particular focus on sex. Grid View

â€œI wanted to create a new groundbreaking version of this show for this moment,â€ Dunn said. â€œOur new Queer as Folk is set in New Orleans â€” one of the most unique queer communities in North America â€” and I am immensely proud that the new series is comprised of an electric ensemble of fresh characters that mirror the modern global audience.â€

As Nadia Vulvokov realized how she was trapped in a never-ending cycle of death and do-overs in Russian Dollâ€™s first season, her familiarity with the concept of time loops helped her escape one. Nadiaâ€™s self-awareness about her predicament was a major part of what kept Russian Doll from feeling like a simple Groundhog Day riff with little to add to the genre. That cosmic knowingness is also one of the reasons Russian Dollâ€™s second season makes for such an unexpectedly different and fascinating puzzle box as it takes the series to its next level with another tale of metaphysical birthday madness.

Russian Dollâ€™s second season picks up a few years after the previous and just days before Nadiaâ€™s (Natasha Lyonne) 40th birthday. As always, Nadia fully intends to spend the day of her birth with loved ones like Maxine (Greta Lee) and Ruth (Elizabeth Ashley), and sheâ€™s confident that sheâ€™s going to be able to make good on her plans because â€” for the first time in a while â€” she feels in control of her life.

More than any specific setting details, itâ€™s Nadiaâ€™s interactions with neighborhood pillars like Horse (Brendan Sexton III) and bodega owner Farran (Ritesh Rajan) that give you a sense of how much everyone has lived in the gap between Russian Dollâ€™s first and second seasons. After spending the past few of Nadiaâ€™s birthdays together and on high alert in case they were sucked into another loop, she and Alan (Charlie Barnett) have had the chance to develop a genuine friendship and shared sense of safety with one another that helps keep them both grounded.

Russian Doll pads its story with a healthy dose of urban legends

Despite Alan and Nadia having more than earned their right to be in perpetual states of anxiety about their places in the universe, Russian Dollâ€™s second chapter leads with the idea that their previous experiences have changed them for the better. Neither Nadia nor Alanâ€™s neuroses are ever all that far away, though, and a substantial part of Russian Dollâ€™s story here is a mind-bending exploration of how the two of them got to be that way in the first place. Similar to how the new season of Russian Doll doesnâ€™t spend as much time reminding you that Nadiaâ€™s a video game developer, the show doesnâ€™t try to frame its new time-traveling conceit as a surprise. Rather, Russian Doll presents it as the universe challenging both Alan and Nadia to better understand themselves and how uniquely situated in reality theyâ€™ve always been.

Russian Doll once again presumes that you, like Nadia, have consumed enough stories about time travel to know the rules about what people should and shouldnâ€™t do if they spontaneously find themselves transported to the distant past. Season two raises the stakes and puts a unique spin on the genre, though, by padding its story with a healthy dose of urban legends and batshit left turns that all complement Lyonneâ€™s performance as a consummate New Yorker who â€” mostly â€” knows no fear.

The importance of living in the moment is one of the larger ideas that shapes much of Russian Dollâ€™s plot as Nadia and Alan begin bouncing back and forth between the present day and important moments from their past that are somehow connected by New Yorkâ€™s subway system. In any other series, the absurdity of a time-traveling MTA train guiding people to crucial points in their lives might almost be enough to derail the entire endeavor, but it works here because of this seasonâ€™s focus on how nonsensical things become important parts of peopleâ€™s identities.

Though much of this season is about Nadia looking back on her life, Russian Doll also delves into her interiority by way of her mother, Lenora (ChloÃ« Sevigny), a paranoid schizophrenic with her own history of moving through the world in ways that â€œnormalâ€ people donâ€™t. Russian Dollâ€™s first season gave us a taste of what Nadiaâ€™s childhood with Lenora was like, but season 2 is a proper study of what it meant for Lenora to be a single mother in the â€™80s struggling to support a family with few resources at her disposal. Both Lyonne â€” who also serves as showrunner â€” and Sevigny bring Nadia and Lenora to life with a raw intensity that feels new despite it gelling with what weâ€™ve seen of the characters in the past.

While Russian Dollâ€™s taking on a slightly different kind of sci-fi / supernatural trope this season, whatâ€™s pleasantly surprising is how uninterested the series is in deconstructing said trope outside of a handful of jokes. Russian Doll knows that youâ€™ve probably seen Back to the Future and thought about what sorts of investments youâ€™d want to make if you woke up in the past, which is why it spends so much of its time pushing you and its protagonists to think more deeply about whatâ€™s happening to them.

The more you settle into the Murakami-like pacing and sensibilities of Russian Dollâ€™s new mystery, the more satisfying this seven-episode-long season ends up being as it begins to increasingly rely on a fuzzy kind of dream logic. The clarity that Nadia and Alan are initially able to view their situations with doesnâ€™t endure, but itâ€™s replaced by a perspective thatâ€™s far more interesting and leaves open the possibility for even more Russian Doll down the line.

Even though weâ€™ve seen a few teasers of Stranger Thingsâ€™ upcoming fourth season, none of them really let on just how much larger and epic in scope this next chapter seems like itâ€™s going to be.

While Stranger Things has explored the larger world outside of Hawkins, Indiana, in the past, the showâ€™s fourth season is set to switch things up by splitting its story across a handful of disparate, important locations. Though the story will presumably return to the Upside Down and catch up with Jim Hopper in Russia, Stranger Thingsâ€™ first season four trailer makes clear that a significant part of its next chapter will unfold in California, where Joyce and the rest of the Byers family have moved.

column1:
In the age of binge-watching and television seasons that drop all at once, Severance feels unique: itâ€™s a show you definitely donâ€™t want to watch in one go. Despite the veneer of a banal workplace drama, Severance is an incredibly tense sci-fi horror series where that tension only builds over the course of the showâ€™s nine episodes. Each new chapter is a chance to see something more messed up and discover the dark depths the capitalist machine is willing to sink to. Youâ€™re going to want some space in between to let it all soak in â€” and maybe catch your breath a little.

This article contains spoilers for the first season of Severance.

Severance starts out fairly slowly. The show centers on a relatively new procedure called, naturally, severance, which splits a workerâ€™s brain in two. This allows people to essentially skip work for eight hours a day and focus on their outside life. The work self, meanwhile (the two are colloquially referred to as â€œinniesâ€ and â€œoutiesâ€), is stuck in a life that is nothing but work. Their entire lives are contained to the office. The technology allows memories to be spatially dictated. Your life and memories are yours right up until you hop in the elevator at Lumon Industries, go down to the severed floor, and get to work. From that point on, your time and memories belong to your innie â€” and to Lumon.

Related The weird computers and claustrophobic hallways of Severance

Weâ€™re introduced to the concept through Mark (Adam Scott). On the outside, Mark is grieving the loss of his wife, and he signed up to be severed in hopes of avoiding those feelings for at least part of the day. On the inside, heâ€™s the chipper department head of the macrodata refinement division at Lumon, where he and three other employees â€” Dylan (Zach Cherry), Helly (Britt Lower), and Irving (John Turturro) â€” spend all day long doingâ€¦ something. Itâ€™s never actually clear what their job is, though theyâ€™re reassured the work is mysterious and important. It mostly involves finding â€œscaryâ€ numbers on a bewildering grid.

Initially, itâ€™s easy to see the appeal of severing. Work sucks. Who wouldnâ€™t want to cut that drudgery out of their lives and focus on the good parts? But it quickly becomes clear just how untenable the solution is. For the innies, itâ€™s an actual nightmare. Their lives exist only within the dreary walls of Lumonâ€™s basement. When they leave work, their next memory is of arriving the next day. They feel the effects of sleep, but they never experience it themselves. Things get so bleak that collecting office trinkets like Lumon-branded finger traps becomes an actual incentive. At one point, a contraband book of New Age philosophical gibberish makes its way into the department, and the refiners treat it like the most important piece of literature ever written. After all, when the only thing youâ€™ve ever read is an employee handbook, anything would be good by comparison.

The sense of discomfort â€” and, eventually, outright terror â€” grows as the show progresses, and you learn more about Lumon and what life is like in the basement. The company itself is a bit like if Amazon was run by Scientologists, only a lot more evil. Weâ€™re told that itâ€™s a pharmaceutical company with its hands in a lot of different industries. Much of the staff â€” at least those we see, including Markâ€™s boss, played with a terrifying intensity by Patricia Arquette â€” worship its founder like a religious figure, right down to the constant repetition of dogma. In the optics and design division, you can find, among other disturbing Romantic era-style paintings of interdepartmental wars, a version of Wanderer above the Sea of Fog, featuring Lumon founder Kier Eagan staring out into the great unknown.

Severance thrives on mystery. Like Lost and Yellowjackets, itâ€™s a show that loves to toss inexplicable curveballs at viewers that are sometimes explained, sometimes not. In Severance, those strange twists are often the reason for the steadily creeping sense of dread. Some of this comes down to the way the show looks: the severed floor is like something out of a parallel dimension. Itâ€™s almost like a cubicle farm ripped out of the â€˜60s, but with strange retrofuturistic computers, twisting hallways designed for maximum confusion, and a breakroom that doubles as a psychological torture chamber. Oh, and thereâ€™s a room filled with baby goats. Itâ€™s the kind of show where a celebratory waffle party inevitably devolves into something bizarre and uncomfortable.

This sense of mystery is amplified by the dual nature of the severed characters. Each actor is essentially playing two different people with conflicting desires. But by nature of their surgically altered brains, they only know half of the story. Outie Mark has no idea what really goes on during the hours heâ€™s at the office, and innie Mark knows literally nothing about the outside world and the impact that widespread adoption of severance could have. You may be confused while watching, but the characters in the show have things much, much worse. I should also note that Severanceâ€™s creators have a clear love of artful cliffhangers of the â€œNot Pennyâ€™s boatâ€ variety. This extends to the finale, which, while answering some important questions and offering some explosive revelations, also leaves a lot to be uncovered in Severanceâ€™s recently confirmed second season. You may shout at your screen when the credits kick in.

Put it all together, and you have a show that paints the darkest possible portrait of how megacorporations think about and treat their employees. Weâ€™ve all seen the stories of what tech giants try to get away with in the real world; Severance posits a future where they can do literally anything in secret because employees have knowingly signed up to be lab rats. If things go Lumonâ€™s way, no one will ever know about the goats or the breakroom. That tension and terror are worth it, though. The first season of Severance is stressful, but itâ€™s also a lot more fun than a Lumon-allocated Music Dance Experience.

column1:
In the vast underground office of Lumon, the megacorporation at the heart of Apple TV Plusâ€™ thriller Severance, the computers are downright bizarre. At first they look a bit like an old Mac, but the closer you look, the more strange they become. The CRT display is somehow a touchscreen. The beautiful blue keyboard is saddled with a gigantic trackball. The goal, production designer Jeremy Hindle tells The Verge, was to design a device that doesnâ€™t make a lot of sense, mirroring the purgatory-like world that exists only within Lumonâ€™s basement. â€œThe idea was that anything you could see underground doesnâ€™t exist up top anywhere,â€ says Hindle. â€œYouâ€™ll never see that computer or that keyboard.â€

This article contains light spoilers for Severance.

Severance takes place in a world where a new procedure â€” the titular severance â€” allows workers to split their lives in two after a little brain surgery. They essentially become two people: one who lives a relatively normal life and another whose entire existence resides in a purgatory-like office. Because of this, the design of the office itself was extremely important. It needed to feel like a place outside of time and space. â€œYou have to make sure that the inside and outside world are [different] enough that youâ€™re immersed in the world, so you feel like youâ€™re severed when youâ€™re down there with them,â€ explains Hindle.

The starting point was offices from the 1960s. â€œTheyâ€™re working in this office environment, and theyâ€™re brought in to just be these pro-workers, and theyâ€™re birthed into the place,â€ Hindle says. â€œIt should be like what offices used to be like. Beautiful desks, beautiful structures, beautiful lights. Just about work. On the desk thereâ€™s one pen, a rolodex, a phone. It felt like it had to be that same tone â€” but way more playful.â€

At first glance, the offices in Severance look fairly normal. Theyâ€™re brightly lit with clean white walls and carpeted green floors. But in the macrodata refinement wing â€” where much of the show takes place â€” things are a little off. Despite having a huge room, the four workers are crammed together via a cluster of desks in the middle of the space. From there, things get even stranger. The hallways, designed with the intention of making people lost, twist and turn in confusing ways, and there are rooms filled with 3D printers and baby goats.

â€œItâ€™s not a spaceship, but it is a spaceship.â€

The breakroom, despite its name, is a bleak, dark place where employees are punished for breaking the rules. In order to access it, theyâ€™re forced down a long, narrow, and dimly lit hallway thatâ€™s barely wide enough for a single person. â€œThe space is what makes people feel uncomfortable when they watch it,â€ says Hindle. â€œIn [macrodata refinement] the ceiling is so low, so even though the room is a football field, itâ€™s claustrophobic in a strange way.â€ (According to Hindle, series creator Dan Erickson once drew him a map of the labyrinth basement, which he describes as a â€œmaze.â€)

The next step was perfecting the smaller details because the underground office is meant to be its own little world. â€œItâ€™s not a spaceship, but it is a spaceship,â€ Hindle says, citing the original Alien as a big source of inspiration. That meant that everything in it, from the desks with their adjustable dividers and the snacks in the vending machine to the finger traps given out as bonuses had to be created in-house. Hindle estimates that the production team designed around 100 different products to be used in the office, all meant to evoke the Lumon aesthetic.

Which takes us back to the computers. â€œWhile the market has quickly turned to favor the buyers, the good news is that it isnâ€™t broken,â€ according to Jeremy Abelson and Jacob Sonnenberg of Irving Investors.

The numbers donâ€™t lie â€” for all but a few strong contenders, the IPO window is now closed.

Senior Editor, TechCrunch+

Cram downs are a character test for VCs and founders

Follow-on investors who take advantage of the closing IPO window to foist unfavorable terms on founders are â€œthe bottom feeders of the venture capital business,â€ writes Steve Blank.

Ultimately, â€œVCs will stop playing this game when founders stop negotiating.â€

How to think like an investor: Understanding the actual cost of fundraising

Founders in fundraising mode are usually laser-focused on the task at hand, but now that valuations are a moving target, it might be useful to borrow an investorâ€™s perspective.

â€œThe presumption that a company knows what its investors expect with full clarity is a lofty one,â€ says Rebecca Mitchem, a partner at Neotribe Ventures.

In a post aimed at growth-stage entrepreneurs, Mitchem answers three questions:

How expensive is venture capital (as defined by the amount of dilution)? What financial milestones will investors expect me to reach between each raise? What are the more subjective milestones I need to hit to evidence Iâ€™m ready for the next raise?

Itâ€™s a difficult problem to solve: driving is a collection of acquired and practiced skills â€“ negotiating a traffic jam requires a much different set of skills than parallel parking.

â€œNobody is going to solve everything. Everybody is going to master one area and then work with others to create that end-to-end ecosystem,â€ Steer Tech founder and CEO Anuja Sonalker told Rebecca Bellan.

In their interview, Sonalker discusses the importance of automotive cybersecurity, how automating the â€œendpointâ€ makes freight more efficient, and why focusing on less glamorous tech can help companies build better products.

â€œMLB has a long history of leveraging data and technology, and being an early adopter of a lot of the technologies, which I love doing,â€ he said.

Netflix is preparing to crack down on password sharing around the world, with the company telling shareholders Tuesday that it is a â€œbig opportunityâ€ for the streaming giant to help turn around its fortunes.

The company reported a quarterly subscriber loss Tuesday, ending Q1 of 2022 with 221.64 million subscribers, down from 221.84 million in Q4 of 2021.

In its shareholder letter, Netflix cited â€œthe large number of households sharing accountsâ€ as a critical factor â€œcreating revenue growth headwinds.â€ Specifically Netflix estimates that â€œover 100 millionâ€ households worldwide are using shared Netflix accounts, including more than 30 million in the U.S. and Canada.

â€œThis is a big opportunity as these households are already watching Netflix and enjoying our service,â€ the company wrote in its letter. â€œSharing likely helped fuel our growth by getting more people using and enjoying Netflix. And weâ€™ve always tried to make sharing within a memberâ€™s household easy, with features like profiles and multiple streams. While these have been very popular, theyâ€™ve created confusion about when and how Netflix can be shared with other households.â€

Netflix began to test out potential password-sharing effort last year, and this March, the company rolled out a pilot program in Costa Rica, Peru and Chile that would let users add additional members outside of their households if the company IDâ€™ed that a password was being shared.

On Tuesday, the company left no doubt that the crackdown will expand in the near future.

â€œThereâ€™s a broad range of engagement when it comes to sharing households from high to occasional viewing,â€ the company said. â€œSo while we wonâ€™t be able to monetize all of it right now, we believe itâ€™s a large short- to mid-term opportunity.â€

Still, Netflix noted that â€œaccount sharing as a percentage of our paying membership hasnâ€™t changed much over the years,â€ but added that the COVID-spurred subscriber pull-forward obscured the impact that password sharing had on its business.

A longtime creative exec, Mo Marable was best known for directing TV titles (see Big Love and the enduringly familiar Entourage opener) before the most unlikely of breaks got him behind the camera of narrative comedies such as The Game, Miracle Workers and Insecure.

It was a short for the 2014 White House Correspondentsâ€™ Dinner, the one where Julia Louis-Dreyfus and then-Vice President Joe Biden darted around D.C. in a cameo-filled parody, that changed the course of his career. Now a producing director on two series â€” Huluâ€™s Woke, which recently dropped its entire second season, and Peacockâ€™s Killing It, which just premiered on April 14 â€” Marable has now worked on nearly 20 series and become a go-to choice for comedy pilots. Zooming in from the Nova Scotia shoot of Huluâ€™s Washington Black adaptation in early April, the director spoke about his trajectory, the increasingly polarizing idea of â€œwokenessâ€ and hopes for his feature debut: a Disney+ update of 1980s comedy Three Men and a Baby.

It only recently came to my attention that you were the one who directed that insane White House Correspondentsâ€™ Dinner video with our now president and Julia Louis-Dreyfus. Howâ€™d you land that?

How I got there was crazy. I used to work at HBO, in the creative services promo department, but I had left and started my own production company. HBO, no matter whoâ€™s there, will always be family to me. They called me to do a promo for Veep, and I was like, â€œI donâ€™t do promos anymore.â€ But then, of course, I shot it. Three weeks later I get a call for another Veep thing. â€œJust read it,â€ they said. So, I did, but I go, â€œWho are we going to get to play Joe Biden?â€ Turns out: Joe Biden. How do you say â€œnoâ€ to that? Next thing I know, Iâ€™m in D.C. and walking around the Oval Office. Every location we had, whether it was in The White House or Congress or whatever, we only had 15 minutes to shoot. I remember at one point the Obamasâ€™ dog [Bo or Sunny] runs in and stops, looks at me, and then just walks out. â€œWrong brother,â€ I said, â€œWrong brother.â€

Going into this, youâ€™d worked with Julia â€” but obviously not with Joe Biden or Michelle Obama, who made a memorable cameo.

Working with Julia and [Veep creator] Armando Iannucci, we just hunkered down for like three or four days and created this piece together. But we had a lot of pivots, like the First Lady. We got a call on the second day saying, â€œMichelle Obama wants in.â€ And you already know what happens. Sheâ€™s all about fitness and eating healthy, but sheâ€™s eating all of that ice cream. We had 15 minutes to shoot that. One thing I will say about Michelle Obama is that she has such a spirit and an energy. You can feel it far away. So weâ€™re in there, and The White House assistants were just like, â€œSheâ€™ll be ready in five minutesâ€¦ two minutesâ€¦â€ all of a sudden all these secret service men are in the room. I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™m making this up, because itâ€™s just the way I thought I saw her, but she came in and she was like, â€œHey!â€

When she hit her time limit, I needed one more shot to make it all work. â€œMaâ€™am, is it OK if I just shoot this one shot?â€ And Joe Biden lit me up. â€œShe is the First Lady of the United States! You just canâ€™t ask her that!â€ And Michelle just goes, â€œJoe.â€ She turns to me and says, â€œMo, what do you need?â€ She says itâ€™s fine, and then Joe just smiles. It was such a wonderful experience, and that was the narrative turning point of my career.

You really started racking up credits at that point.



That hit on Saturday night, during Correspondentsâ€™ Dinner, and then it was all over the news. That Monday I got a phone call to direct a TV show. It happened, just like that.

You hear a lot about directors shifting from music videos to TV and features but not from branded content. Do you think that you wouldâ€™ve been able to segue into the career you have now without that moment?



I donâ€™t know. My goal was always to become a director. When youâ€™re young, you just think like everythingâ€™s possible. You donâ€™t even know what the game is. You donâ€™t know that some of this is inside baseball or nepotism. Not everybody who works hard and does good work gets to win. I got to a point where I was just satisfied that I wasnâ€™t broke. â€œOh, I can go on a vacation with my friends? Well, if I donâ€™t ever do narrative, thatâ€™s cool.â€ But the reality is I never doubted that I was going to transition at some point.

The very first show they gave me a shot was The Game, Mara [Brock] and Salim Akil. That was the first phone call I got the day after the Correspondentsâ€™ Dinner thing came out. And in this business, you need somebody to vouch for you. You need somebody to say, â€œTake that shot.â€ Then I directed Veep, which I think wouldâ€™ve happened anyway because of the short. From there it was Itâ€™s Always Sunny in Philadelphia and things just picked up.

Since Woke originally premiered almost two years ago â€” and the timing of it is still kind of surreal, since that long-ignored conversation really came to the fore that summer â€” some things have changed and simultaneously nothing has change. But one big development is the that term â€œwokeâ€ has been weaponized by the right.

When we sold the show, and again when we were getting ready to market it, we had a lot of meetings around, â€œShould we keep the name Woke?â€ Woke was already starting to feel overused. We batted all of these other ideas around, but at the end of the day we kept coming back to Woke. It was timely, because people were paying attention. Like you said, itâ€™s always been there. Sadly, between George Floyd and a pandemic, there were just so many things at play. We were actually supposed to premiere the show maybe six weeks or eight weeks later â€” during election week, I think! Hulu was a real partner for doing everything to push it forward, throwing money at marketing to get it all going. But the word â€œwokeâ€ has been twisted and co-opted. Itâ€™s a slur in certain circles. Thatâ€™s the reason our tagline this season is â€œWoke is a four-letter word.â€

For sure, and the new season really gets into the complications of the term and even within the activist community.

Itâ€™s a racial slur and a kind of microaggression in certain areas. I donâ€™t know who is proud of the word anymore â€” and Iâ€™m talking every group from the right to the left. What I think the show loves about it now is that it is so polarized. And the thing about wokeness is â€¦ can anybody truly be woke? After George Floyd happened, next thing you know there are corporations putting out so-called woke type messaging. Huh!? I had a neighbor bring over food after George Floyd was murdered. I remember standing in the yard by the porch and my wife was out front and I just saw it coming. Hereâ€™s the casserole. Then I heard, â€œIâ€™m so sorry.â€ I was like, â€œI donâ€™t fucking know Floyd like that! Iâ€™m not at the wake.â€ The symbol of what happened galvanized me, galvanized a lot of people, but then Iâ€™d get a phone call from somebody who I hadnâ€™t worked with in 20 years, someone I donâ€™t really know, saying â€œHey, if you can, can you give me a call back? I just really want to talk to you, man.â€ Oh my God. Iâ€™m the one black friend for someone. So, part of Woke this season is about the misuse of the idea of wokeness. The idea that corporations try to co-opt it to make more money as a marketing tool. The idea that you can never really be woke. The idea that a lot of our woke leaders started making money.

The set-up for Killing It is almost too absurd to get into. How did you come to direct that pilot?



I had just done another pilot with Dan Goor, Grand Crew for NBC, so I read it and I just thought the script was hilarious â€” especially knowing that was Craig Robinson. Itâ€™s so weird. But I loved it because I never see these types of people â€” especially people of color and women â€” in this kind of space. Whoâ€™s going to think that Craig Robinson is going to play a snake hunter in the Florida bayous? Nobody. But this is what Iâ€™m trying to do nowadays. Iâ€™m now in a space where I really try to pick projects that actually have a social undercurrent. Weâ€™re talking about something. You may not see it right away, but if you start to pay attention, itâ€™ll get closer and closer to you.

Iâ€™m not as outwardly political. Yes, I vote. I will go to a march. I will donate. If something in the workplace is not right, Iâ€™m going to speak up. But as a person out there, Iâ€™m not door-knocking. And sometimes I wonder: Am I doing enough? And I think where I do my best political work is in my work. At the end of the day, I really want to normalize African Americans and talk about the idea that the system is built to not allow everybody a piece of the pie.

Fewer and fewer people every year.

Every year. And [Robinsonâ€™s character] is just trying so hard to find a way to get his little plot of land. Heâ€™s not trying to be a criminal. Heâ€™s trying to do it the legit way, yet still he has a brother whoâ€™s like, â€œNah, thatâ€™s not going to work.â€ It shows you this idea of how people get ahead. Being corrupt seems to have worked for a lot of people. Doing it the hard way hasnâ€™t worked for some people, especially for people who have been marginalized already. I just find this tale of trying to achieve the American dream to be sad and real â€” even though we disguise it in all this crazy comedy.

You have to tell me something about your Three Men and a Baby reboot for Disney+. Whatâ€™s your angle?

Well, hereâ€™s what I will say. I mean, again, Iâ€™m trying not to do anything that doesnâ€™t speak to whatâ€™s going on in society today. When you go back and you watch the original Three Men and a Baby you go, â€œtimes have changed.â€

Yes, hopefully these protagonists will have a different relationship with women,

Exactly. Thatâ€™s a part of it. Zac Efron is still attached to play the lead. We are in the process of finishing up the script. Iâ€™m not making a Manhattan story. I making a Brooklyn story. Itâ€™s about these three guys, but guys are not as stupid as they were back in the day. The cast will be very diverse, thatâ€™s the only way I would do it, and weâ€™ll see how Disney enjoys the script in the next six/seven weeks.

Will there be a reference to the weird ghost child cameo that was actually just the shadow of the cardboard cut-out of Ted Danson and a top hat?



If I get my druthers, yes. And I would love to have a cameo from one or all of them. I still want to pay homage to the original.

His astrological shows also aired for decades in Latin America and the United States.

â€œI can think of no better partners than 3Pas Studios and A Really Good Home Pictures to present Walterâ€™s life to the generations that loved him and those to come,â€ said Theodore B. Gekis, who manages Mercadoâ€™s estate and will oversee all projects that come through the deal. â€œAlthough Walter has passed on, his message about self-empowerment, self-acceptance and our interconnectedness with the universe live on in humankind and need to be celebrated daily. The latter trio continue to publish horoscopes and other astrology under the banner of Las Estrellas de Walter. â€œAll of Walterâ€™s nieces are excited that 3Pas Studios and Eugenio Derbez along with Andy Fraser and A Really Good Home Pictures will work together to help carry on our uncle Walterâ€™s message of love, positivity and inclusion and introduce his legacy to new generations,â€ said Dannette Benet Mercado.

â€œI knew that we would need a partner with strong connections to Walterâ€™s legacy â€” one that would also respect and continue to spread the love and community that Walter championed in life. 3Pas Studios, with Eugenio, Ben and Sonia, is an excellent fit and Iâ€™m thrilled they came on board,â€ said Fraser.

Music executive Clarence Avant (L) and Jacqueline Avant attend the BET AWARDS '14 Debra Lee's Pre-Dinner held at Milk Studios on June 28, 2014 in Los Angeles, California.

A parolee who murdered 81-year-old philanthropist Jacqueline Avant, the wife of a legendary music executive, was sentenced Tuesday to 190 years in a California prison.

Aariel Maynor, 30, pleaded guilty to murder and other charges in Los Angeles Superior Court last month and admitted he used an AR-15 style semi-automatic rifle to shoot Avant in her Beverly Hills home Dec. 1 and fired several rounds at her security guard as he fled.

Avant was married to Clarence Avant, a Grammy winner known as the â€œGodfather of Black Musicâ€ for mentoring and helping the careers of artists including Bill Withers, Little Willie John, L.A. Reid, Babyface, Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis.

Maynor shot Jacqueline Avant in the back when she surprised him after he broke into the coupleâ€™s house during a burglary attempt in which he hoped to steal $50,000, prosecutors said. After fleeing the scene, he broke into a home in the Hollywood Hills and then accidentally shot himself in the foot as he was leaving.

Avant used her money for charities that helped low-income neighborhoods such as Watts and South Los Angeles. She was on the board of the International Student Center at the University of California, Los Angeles.

Clarence Avant, 91, a concert promoter and manager, was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame last year.

Prosecutors said Maynor had searched for information on Clarence Avant and the coupleâ€™s address the day before the killing.

Maynor showed no remorse for the slaying, bragging to a friend on a jail phone call about all the news stories about him and laughing, according to a court document filed by Deputy District Attorney Victor Avila.

â€œYou think my mamaâ€™s seen that?â€ he asked.

â€œI donâ€™t know, but thatâ€™s not funny,â€ the woman, who was not identified, said. â€œWhy are you laughinâ€™? Thatâ€™s somebodyâ€™s life. Thatâ€™s somebodyâ€™s family member.â€

The Avants were married for 54 years and had two children, Alexander Du Bois Avant and Nicole Avant, a film producer and former U.S. ambassador to the Bahamas who is married to Netflix co-CEO and Chief Content Officer Ted Sarandos.

After Jacqueline Avantâ€™s death, tributes were paid to her and her charitable work by former President Bill Clinton, Earvin â€œMagicâ€ Johnson and Quincy Jones.

Maynor, who was on parole for his second robbery conviction, bragged to a friend during a jail call that he expected a shorter sentence because prosecutors were not seeking life without parole.

â€œIâ€™m gonna get out of jail. Iâ€™ll probably do like 20 â€¦ 25, get out, you feel me?â€ he said.

Under District Attorney George GascÃ³n, the office did not seek a special circumstance allegation that the killing was committed in the act of a burglary, which could have led to a possible sentence of life without parole.

Instead, prosecutors sought an enhanced penalty under the Three Strikes law where a third serious or violent felony can trigger a life sentence.

column1:
The last time I prayed, it was awkward â€” a reflection, really, of my relationship with God.

Iâ€™m sure with everything going on, the Lord isnâ€™t judging me for my extended hiatus. But on that evening many months ago, when I decided to kneel beside my bed, clasp my hands and shut my eyes, I sincerely wondered if God was mad at me.

I wanted to ease the tension between us, so, naturally, I started my prayer with a joke: a brief bit about my absence, the state of the world, my anxieties, existential malaise. And it worked. My body loosened. My words become more animated, my storytelling more energetic. Humor has a way of doing that â€” soothing nerves and clearing the way for a sometimes destabilizing level of honesty.

I thought about my conversation with God while watching Jerrod Carmichaelâ€™s Rothaniel, a stunning and unnerving act of storytelling. The hour-long special, which premiered on HBO in early April, has already been written about considerably, with critics observing how it pushes stand-up into the realm of confession and functions as group therapy, or focusing on Carmichaelâ€™s brilliant use of silences, his coming out as gay and his engagement with the live audience. These pieces have rightly folded Carmichael into a new class of introspective, intimate stand-up specials, which include Hannah Gadsbyâ€™s Nanette, Bo Burnhamâ€™s Inside and even Pete Davidsonâ€™s Alive from New York.

I agree with many of these readings. But watching Rothaniel for a second, and then third, time, I couldnâ€™t shake the feeling that Carmichael was doing something more: that this comedian, who has already released two stand-up specials, a short-lived sitcom and a pair of brief personal documentaries â€” material in which he gestures at his sexuality, explores family secrets, confronts his parents and demonstrates a desire to build rapport with the audience â€” was trying to really push himself and viewers. Buoyed by the freedom found within humor, Rothaniel struck me as a delicate movement between different forms of storytelling â€” a work that begins as confessional comedy, is organized like a memoir and is finally imbued with and sustained by the ecstatic energy of prayer.

Carmichael is a man of faith, although, as he says in Rothaniel, coming out as gay has forced him to redefine what that means. Religion, the church and the Bible have, for the most part, always made appearances in his work. In Love at the Store, his first special, directed by Spike Lee, he jokes about Michael Jackson reaching the gates of heaven, presenting St. Peter and the Lord with a conundrum. They are fans of the star, but they are also the moral authorities: Can they let the King of Pop in amid the accusations against him? In 8, directed by Bo Burnham, who also directed Rothaniel, Carmichael presents an absence of faith, performing an extended bit about how he struggles to care and feel strongly about any issues. His family in The Carmichael Show was deeply religious and in his two documentaries, Home Videos and Sermon on the Mount, both directed by the comedian himself, he grapples with the tension between his motherâ€™s faith, his fatherâ€™s infidelity and his familyâ€™s penchant for keeping secrets.

In Rothaniel, Carmichael returns to the subject of secrets. He is older now, much more in command of himself. You can tell just by the smoothness with which he gets on stage, takes a seat and addresses the applauding crowd shadowed by the darkness of the Blue Note Jazz Club in New York. His performing and storytelling abilities are sharper, too, allowing him to achieve a new degree of candor.

Carmichael opens with a handful of jokes that show off his signature style of humor. These jabs about the number of affairs in his family history, about his grandmother being a â€œside-piece,â€ about the embarrassment around his real name get the crowd going, but they are also a warm-up, allowing Carmichael to ease himself into the space and the crowd. In a recent talk for the New York Public Library, the critic and memoirist Margo Jefferson, whom Carmichael reminds me of, observed how humor factored into her own work. It allowed her to â€œbreak through my decorum, my anxiety,â€ she said, which led her to â€œother tones, to acknowledge a sort of grief, a sort of self-abnegation.â€

Humor serves a similar function in Rothaniel. It allows Carmichael to access a more honest register in this story he has decided to share. In his previous work and in interviews about the special, the comedian has hinted at the suffocating role decorum and politesse play in his family, how they poison conversations and attempts to bridge gaps of understanding. As Carmichael moves from historical affairs to the present, his special transcends the introspective comedy of late and enters the realm of memoir. The contours of the narrative become clearer: This is a story about how revealing another personâ€™s secrets (specifically, telling his mother about his fatherâ€™s cheating) forced Carmichael to confess his own, and how that admission did not lead to immediate catharsis.

When he comes out, his silences serve as interludes, marking a shift in the story. Carmichael never abandons the humor, but he does lower the volume. The audience becomes louder as they chime in with prompting questions and affirmative statements of love and support. But when Carmichael starts talking about his mother, a central character in many of his stories, I couldnâ€™t help but feel as though he is speaking to someone beyond the people in the audience and viewers at home. The perspective changes, too. Carmichaelâ€™s face occupies the left edge of the frame; when he shakes his head in disbelief at his motherâ€™s responses to him, he looks up, away, elsewhere.

Rothaniel, then, starts to feel like a searching prayer, a conversation with God after a long hiatus. Carmichael starts and then abandons thoughts about his mother. He recalls how she told him, in a previous conversation about being gay, that she â€œcanâ€™t go against Jesus.â€ He follows that by saying he understands that she is trying her best. Prayer isnâ€™t always about request or gratitude. Much like journaling or therapy or talking to a friend, it can help you make sense of the world.

The latter half of Carmichaelâ€™s special plays like a communion, a spiritual meeting between him, his familyâ€™s past and the unknown terrain of their future. Sitting on the stage, the comedian wears a loneliness familiar to anyone whose survival and self-preservation are at odds with the narratives maintained by their loved ones. To share that experience â€” with all the relief, confusion and discomfort that come with it â€” and to trust that those watching will follow is, to me, an extraordinary act of faith.
column2: Lovia Gyarkye

The Goldbergs is making it to the decade mark.

The 1980s-set comedy has been renewed for its 10th season on ABC. The renewal arrives a month after star and exec producer Wendi McLendon-Covey signed a new deal to return with producers Sony Pictures Television. The pact, which sources note includes an option for an 11th season, included a sizable pay bump.

With the pickup, The Goldbergs becomes part of an increasingly exclusive club of live-action broadcast comedies to have run for a decade or more. That list includes Friends, Married â€¦ With Children, The Jeffersons, Cheers, Frasier (which is also returning with a Paramount+ revival), M*A*S*H, Modern Family, Two and a Half Men, The Big Bang Theory and Will & Grace (with that tally including its NBC revival).

Before McLendon-Coveyâ€™s new deal, The Goldbergs was strongly on the bubble despite its ranking as the longest-running live-action comedy currently airing on broadcast. The show has had a challenging ninth season and had to write in the death of George Segal (who played the beloved Pops) and is currently working around the departure of star Jeff Garlin.

Garlin, who played patriarch Murray Goldberg, exited in December following an HR investigation that stemmed from multiple complaints over his behavior on the set of the comedy. Sources at the time described the decision as a mutual one between Garlin and Sony. At the time, he was not expected to return for the potential and now-confirmed 10th season.

The Goldbergs had been relatively free of controversy during its run. The series weathered sexual misconduct allegations around former recurring player Bryan Callen, who toplined ABC/Sonyâ€™s short-lived 1990s-set spinoff, Schooled. Callen has not appeared on The Goldbergs since the allegations came out in a July 2020 Los Angeles Times report. (Callen denied the allegations.)

The Goldbergs is a semiautobiographical comedy based on the childhood of series creator Adam F. Goldberg. Goldberg served as showrunner until season seven, when he moved his overall deal from Sony to Disney. Alex Barnow and Chris Bishop â€” who have been with series since its debut â€” have helmed the show since then and exec produce alongside Doug Robinson and star McLendon-Covey, among others. The cast also includes Sean Giambrone, Troy Gentile, Hayley Orrantia and Sam Lerner.

The Goldbergs joins a roster of returning scripted fare on ABCâ€™s 2022-23 schedule that also includes dramas The Good Doctor, Greyâ€™s Anatomy, The Rookie, Station 19 and comedy breakout Abbott Elementary.

column1:
Sean Penn, Julia Roberts, Dan Stevens and Betty Gilpin attend the "Gaslit" New York Premiere at Metropolitan Museum of Art on April 18, 2022 in New York City.

New York Cityâ€™s Metropolitan Museum of Art was transformed into the red â€” or, rather, yellow â€” carpet on Monday for the world premiere of Starzâ€™s upcoming political thriller Gaslit, starring Julia Roberts and Sean Penn.

The series â€” which also features Dan Stevens and Betty Gilpin â€” is described as a modern take on Watergate that focuses on the untold stories and forgotten characters of the scandal and centers on Martha Mitchell (Roberts), an Arkansan socialite and wife to John Mitchell (Penn), Richard Nixonâ€™s attorney general. Martha was the first to publicly sound the alarm on the former presidentâ€™s involvement in the Watergate scandal, which caused his presidency and her personal life to unravel.

Showrunner Robbie Pickering said his interest in Nixon and Watergate began when he was a child, and he saw his mom crying while watching his funeral on TV.

â€œShe said, â€˜He was a good man. He was a great man. He was misunderstood. And the liberals did this to him,â€ Pickering told The Hollywood Reporter. â€œI was like, â€˜Iâ€™ve got to know everything about this guy.â€™ And I started learning about the people around him and this weird culture around him of complicity and cultural bitterness, which we still have today.â€

The creator said he took inspiration from the worst qualities of himself and the people he knows and wrote them into the fictionalized version of Gaslitâ€˜s real-life characters.

â€œThe show really explores complicity and why people do horrible things,â€ he said. â€œOne of the reasons is ambition. So, John Dean (Stevens) is just me writing myself as a young person in Hollywood, writing terrible scripts to impress somebody. John Mitchell, whoâ€™s Sean Pennâ€™s character, just feels valued by Nixon. He feels valued by somebody in power, and I think we all know what thatâ€™s like to feel â€” itâ€™s just this weird, seductive feeling.â€

Despite the many flaws of the seriesâ€™ characters, Pickering said creating a show from their perspective gives him hope because it humanized the â€œpathetic idiotsâ€ a bit, adding that some people are prone to be complicit in things that go against who they are.

â€œIt gives me hope because the flip side of that is no matter how flawed we think we are, we all have the capacity to speak up and speak the truth and be heroic,â€ he says. â€œMartha was a very flawed person, so really going into her story, it gives you hope for as long as we have villainsâ€¦ as long as we have Putins, weâ€™ll have Zelenskys.â€

Because Gaslit is based on actual events and real people, the cast was able to deep dive into researching their onscreen counterparts â€” who they were, why they did the things they did and how they got to that point in their lives.

â€œI read Mo Deanâ€™s book, A Womanâ€™s View of Watergate, and I watched hours of the Watergate hearings, where sheâ€™s supporting her husband,â€ said Betty Gilpin, who portrays Maureen â€œMoâ€ Dean, wife of Nixonâ€™s White House Counsel John Dean. â€œThereâ€™s so much going on behind her eyes, sheâ€™s such an enigma.â€

Stevens also used the Watergate hearings to prepare for his role, which piqued his interest because it was â€œsuch a key momentâ€ in history and â€œsuch an interesting story.â€

â€œThereâ€™s a lot of footage of John Dean, sitting, droning on during the hearings, and heâ€™s wheeled out on CNN pretty regularly as their resident corruption expert,â€ Stevens said.

Gilpin and Stevens star alongside Roberts and Penn, who take on the lead roles in Gaslit. The A-listers wanted to work together for years before finally getting the chance to in the Starz series, Pickering said, adding, â€œThereâ€™s this very deep love between them.â€

Gaslit premieres on Starz on Sunday.

column1:
First-quarter filming in Los Angeles set a new record to start the year despite an escalating slide in feature film production.

Local film office FilmLA attributed the drop-off to productions being lured by more attractive tax incentives in other jurisdictions and a shortage of soundstage space in the area. According to a new report issued on Tuesday, feature film shoots saw a 25 percent dip below the five year average in the first quarter of 2022.

â€œItâ€™s doing really well worldwide, but weâ€™ve lost our share of it for years now,â€ FilmLA president Paul Audley tells The Hollywood Reporter.

Although the pace of production has slowed compared to the end of last year, output is much higher so far than it was in the same period in 2021 when the spread of the Delta variant led to a voluntary filming hiatus that slowed production to just 7,011 shoot days. FilmLA reported that the first quarter of 2022 was the busiest first quarter ever, with 9,832 shoot days. The last time there was such high filming levels from January through March was in 2016.

TV filming, especially drama and reality shows, drove the surge, the film office said. TV production is up 18.7 percent over the same period last year.

But shooting for feature films continued on a steady downward trajectory, according to the report. Despite a slight uptick in production compared to last year, the category remains 25.2 percent below its five year average (FilmLAâ€™s five year averages exclude 2020 when production was suspended in Los Angeles from March to June because of COVID-19).

Productions have turned to shooting outside of California to take advantage of more generous tax incentives. Georgia, for example, offers a 30 percent tax credit with no annual cap on its program. The credit is also transferable, meaning projects can sell it to companies that owe taxes. California remains one of just two states whose credits are largely nontransferable and nonrefundable.

The perception that Californiaâ€™s tax credits are less competitive than other states combined with a shortage of soundstage space in Los Angeles has led to the decline in feature film production, Audley observed. He said, â€œIf you need to shoot a feature that needs six, seven, eight stages, itâ€™s impossible to do that now.â€

In July, Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a bill (SB144) meant to tackle the soundstage shortfall. It includes a new $150 million credit to incentivize the construction of sets.

Locally filmed projects include Netflixâ€™s Me Time, Home Delivery, Love Me to Death and Rooming with Danger.

Television has become a mainstay of production in Los Angeles, filling the gap that the flight of feature film shoots have left. Audley said the first quarter filming record is at least partially a result of a backlog of productions that pivoted to shooting locally after realizing that going elsewhere would be more costly and troublesome because of COVID-19 restrictions.

â€œAs the COVID era continued, a lot of productions couldnâ€™t leave their base,â€ Audley said. â€œTheyâ€™d have to quarantine for two weeks if they went to other parts of the country. Those productions ended up staying here in LA.â€

Production for HBOâ€™s The Flight Attendant moved from New York to Los Angeles in 2021.

FilmLA reported that filming for episodic dramas saw a 8.6 percent increase over the five-year average, owing to a significant demand for content on streaming platforms. TV dramas that filmed locally include FXâ€™s American Horror Stories, Apple TV+â€™s Little America, HBOâ€™s Perry Mason, ABCâ€™s Promised Land and CBSâ€™ S.W.A.T.

Tax incentives are a significant driver of local TV dramas choosing to shoot in Los Angeles. Shows receiving tax credits generated 499 shoot days for the quarter, representing 39 percent of all activity in the category.

California bolstered in July the Film & Television Tax Credit program with an additional $180 million in incentives on top of the $330 million already earmarked for the industry. Part of the program is geared specifically toward incentivizing TV productions to relocate to California.

As in recent quarters, TV reality production continued to significantly escalate. Filming for the category increased 71.7 percent, with 2,600 shoot days to start the year. Projects that filmed locally include Basketball Wives, Celebrity IOU, Family or FiancÃ© and People Magazine Investigates.

â€œSeeing cycles in production for all of these [categories] is not unusual,â€ Audley said. â€œThe explosion of reality tv has to do with covid era where they could do those productions with not a lot of cast and crew and not have a lot of issues.â€
